prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Defences to Claims for Breach of Confidential Business Information

para.paratext: If confidential information is discovered, by independent development of the product using publicly available material, an examination of the product, or any other legal means, the discoverer has the right to use the information, and the defence of reverse engineering should be pleaded. This is one of the significant differences between confidential business information and patents. In R.L. Crain Ltd. v. Ashton,[1] it was stated that the interdependency of the parts of a mechanical machine can be determined by “reverse engineering”. Once the presses in this case were sold, the so-called “trade secrets” were open for viewing by any member of the public and could easily be obtained by reverse engineering. The appeal to protect the information failed on the ground that the information was no longer confidential.

In Molnar Lithographic Supplies Ltd. v. Sikatory,[2] the plaintiff wished to protect a chemical formula and manufacturing process for a deep-etch coating solution. It claimed that the defendant was selling this solution, the details of which were obtained while the defendant was working for the plaintiff. The court found that the defendant had developed the formula for his solution by himself, using available publications and extensive experimentation (reverse engineering). The defendant's resulting formula differed from the plaintiff's in one crucial respect, further demonstrating that no duplication had occurred. The court held that, since the defendant had obtained the information by reverse engineering, the action for breach of confidential business information should be dismissed.[3]
Molnar Lithographic Supplies Ltd. v. Sikatory (1974), 14 C.P.R. (2d) 197 (Ont. C.A.).
